<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 813, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 609, 151]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 567, 182]]<|/det|>
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 191, 895, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 390, 532, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 144, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 422, 445, 440]]<|/det|>
Remove the lid from beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 437, 683, 455]]<|/det|>
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 453, 589, 470]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
In the first row of Table 1.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Record, in Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 592, 546, 610]]<|/det|>
Remove the thermometer from the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 623, 144, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 623, 180, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 623, 395, 641]]<|/det|>
Repeat (a) for beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 623, 920, 641]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 653, 180, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 653, 579, 672]]<|/det|>
Add units to the column headings in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 653, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 42, 478, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 101, 836, 361]]<|/det|>

with insulation		beaker B

Justify your answer by reference to values from your results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 518, 920, 536]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 549, 146, 568]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 549, 175, 568]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 549, 920, 584]]<|/det|> Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 106, 562, 134]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 653, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will compare the resistances of two wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 410, 104]]<|/det|>
The circuit has been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 576, 135]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 144, 824, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 420, 532, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 144, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 729, 470]]<|/det|>
Connect the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 90.0 \text{cm}\) of resistance wire A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 482, 299, 500]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 513, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the value of potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) and current \(I\) for the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 297, 577]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 749, 608]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(90.0 \text{cm}\) of wire A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 524, 640]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 637, 529, 668]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{V}{I}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 790, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 579, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the strength of an electromagnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The electromagnet is made from a coil of insulated wire wrapped around an iron rod. When there is an electric current in the coil, the iron rod becomes magnetised. The electromagnet can then attract magnetic materials (e.g. iron and steel).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the number of steel paper clips the electromagnet can support.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 522, 229]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 400, 260]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 413, 306]]<|/det|>
Â· a selection of steel paper clips.
